Award.AwardTitle: UNS:ADVANCING CELL-PRESERVING SEPARATION VIA DETACHABLE CELL ANCHORING & SPIRAL MICRO-MIXING

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512598
Imoukhuede
Uof Ill Urbana-Champaign

Cell separation is especially necessary to advance personalized cancer medicine, because tumors contain a diverse mix of cells with different biomarkers that makes them difficult to treat. If different tumor cell types can be separated and analyzed the promise of tailoring drugs to the unique characteristics of a patient's tumor may be analyzed. The proposed research aims to engineer a fast and gentle cell separation system on a microscale.

The ability to capture cells onto a surface and release by targeting a secondary moiety within the anchor would enable gentler, cell separation. As such, the proposed research aims to combine spiral micro-mixing with cell anchoring and secondary moiety targeted cell release to enable a cell separation from blood that is also receptor-preserving. The specific research goals are as follows: (1) identify the optimum conditions for detachable cell-anchoring; (2) determine the spiral micro-mixer design parameters enabling detachable cell-anchoring; (3) develop the microfluidic platform that will separate circulating endothelial cells, immune cells, and tumor cells from blood samples while preserving surface receptors on isolated cells. The proposed work may develop innovative technology that advances science while championing a high-impact, educational mission.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cell separation is an essential procedure to several biological research areas. It is especially necessary in cancer biology. Here, the diverse mix of cells within tumors, also described as tumor heterogeneity, renders the tumors difficult to treat.  Being able to separate specific cells from the tumor would allow these cells to be measured and used to predict a patient?s status and even their response to drugs. However, cell separation has not yet achieved this promise, because current approaches are expensive and take several hours for cell preparation and sorting.

 

This proposal aimed overcome these limitations by developing a fast and gentle cell separation approach. We achieved this cell separation goal by addressing three (3) critical limitations, as follows: (1) We identified the optimum conditions for detachable cell-anchoring; (2) we determined the spiral micro-mixer design parameters enabling detachable cell-anchoring; and (3) we developed the microfluidic platform separates cells while preserving selected cell biomarkers.

 

This project had several areas of impact.  First, we contributed new knowledge to the cell separation field through our published manuscripts, video demonstration, presentations, and abstracts in conference proceedings.  Indeed, our technology was awarded and recognized within our community.  We developed innovative technology, which can be adapted for separating several types of cells. We also championed a high-impact, educational mission, which broadened participation in engineering and science by providing interdisciplinary training and mentoring to the next generation of bioengineering researchers: at the high school, undergraduate (REU), and graduate level. Additionally, we trained a high school student. Additionally, we recruited and trained a significant number of women and racialized researchers. Together, the proposed efforts supported new pathways into engineering through outreach and education and addressed significant, unmet needs in cell separation through innovation.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Cell separation is an essential procedure to several biological research areas. It is especially necessary in cancer biology. Here, the diverse mix of cells within tumors, also described as tumor heterogeneity, renders the tumors difficult to treat. Being able to separate specific cells from the tumor would allow these cells to be measured and used to predict a patient?s status and even their response to drugs. However, cell separation has not yet achieved this promise, because current approaches are expensive and take several hours for cell preparation and sorting. This proposal aimed overcome these limitations by developing a fast and gentle cell separation approach. We achieved this cell separation goal by addressing three (3) critical limitations, as follows: (1) We identified the optimum conditions for detachable cell-anchoring; (2) we determined the spiral micro-mixer design parameters enabling detachable cell-anchoring; and (3) we developed the microfluidic platform separates cells while preserving selected cell biomarkers. This project had several areas of impact. First, we contributed new knowledge to the cell separation field through our published manuscripts, video demonstration, presentations, and abstracts in conference proceedings. Indeed, our technology was awarded and recognized within our community. We developed innovative technology, which can be adapted for separating several types of cells. We also championed a high-impact, educational mission, which broadened participation in engineering and science by providing interdisciplinary training and mentoring to the next generation of bioengineering researchers: at the high school, undergraduate (REU), and graduate level. Additionally, we trained a high school student. Additionally, we recruited and trained a significant number of women and racialized researchers. Together, the proposed efforts supported new pathways into engineering through outreach and education and addressed significant, unmet needs in cell separation through innovation.
